div.head: To polish a ruby balay
div.ab: You don't polish it with tripoli but like the others, but with marcasite powder and oil.

You need to calcine your fine gold with ☿ and then wipe your amalgam well & make the said mercury fly off. Next crush it on marble with gum water. As for silver one needs to take it straight away & eat away at it with aqua fortis, then take it out with a copper blade & rinse it thoroughly and next grind it with gum water.

div.head: Polishing stones
div.ab: There are three wheels for this purpose, one of tin, one of lead, and one of pure copper. On the cucopper wheel, one does not commonly cut co or polish other than the diamond,the ruby, sapphire and oriental jacinth. The tin wheel is for softer stones such as emeralds, amethysts and others.

div.head: Pewterers' mixture
div.ab: Because they often mix in with the fine tin half the quantity of lead, which renders the tin dull. To correct this, they mix in some latten filings to make it sonorous.

div.head: Perfect amalgam
div.ab: Take the most delicate stoneware you can find, with a cavity in the middle. Put in an eighth part of ☿ in & rub it & wear it down while adding water, urc, ☾ or ☼ until the substance becomes paste-like & even harder. Next, if you want, eat it away with good aqua fortis, if it is ☾ or ♀. Then remelt it, having taken it out as you know. The ☾ will be tinted, and having been melted, will leave some grains of ☼, & the ♀ will be very fine & will have almost no chappe.
